cards.back: A variation of a physical property (voltage, temperature, pressure, etc.) over an independent variable such as time or space.
An interconnection of components that transforms an input signal x(t) into an output signal y(t).

CT: x(t) with parentheses, defined for all real t
DT: x[n] with square brackets, defined only for integer n

cards.front: Energy of a continuous-time signal formula
Average power of a signal formula
When is a signal an energy signal?
cards.back:
When it has finite energy (E < ∞) and therefore zero average power (P = 0).
Example: Pulses, decaying exponentials

cards.front: When is a signal a power signal?
cards.back:
When it has finite average power (0 < P < ∞) and therefore infinite energy (E = ∞).
Example: Sinusoids, constants, periodic signals

cards.front: What makes a signal even? Odd?
cards.back:
Even: x(t) = x(-t) (mirror symmetry about y-axis)
Odd: x(t) = -x(-t) (rotation symmetry about origin)

Even component: $x_e(t) = \frac{x(t) + x(-t)}{2}$
Odd component: $x_o(t) = \frac{x(t) - x(-t)}{2}$
Any signal: x(t) = x_e(t) + x_o(t)

When x(t) = x(t + T) for all t, where T is the period.
The fundamental period T₀ is the smallest positive T satisfying this.

$$T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = \frac{1}{f}$$
where ω is angular frequency (rad/s) and f is frequency (Hz)

$$e^{j\theta} = \cos(\theta) + j\sin(\theta)$$
